posts.name: Roxxy S
posts.cooked: Hello CD ! My team is thinking about getting new design laptops this year (all our functioning ones have been taken by programming) so that we can have a more accessible way to do CAD work both in the lab and at home. Any recommendations for laptops that can run Autodesk Fusion 360 smoothly and preferably cost <$1000 USD per device? At this point I’m sure anything will run better than the school-provided Chromebooks all of us are using right now.

posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked: As long as it has a dedicated gpu, good wifi card it should work well. Touchscreen is not a must have. Any dedicated cheap “gaming” laptop should work great because it has a gpu made to render 3d scenes. If you are gonna be running stimulations you would want a fast cpu tho

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: My friend just picked up one of these and it is really nice and would work well for CAD. HP Victus

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: I know this isn’t responding to the question per se, so apologies if this doesn’t help. If yall are set on fusion/have a good workflow already then feel free to ignore this, but one of the advantages of onshape is that a lot of calculations are done on the server side, which means even Chromebooks can use it. Just food for thought.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: I will say, Chromebooks won’t run Onshape smoothly

posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked: Many chromebooks have small screens and slow processors and wifi so they are a pain to use, speaking from experience. The screen cuts a lot of stuff of, so you have to go into full screen to see a lot of all the options in the mini tabs which tripps up a lot of new users

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Yeah I wouldn’t recommend it, I just mean it’s theoretically possible.

posts.name: Roxxy S
posts.cooked: Yeah all of our CAD training is focused around designing in Fusion so the move to Onshape would require our current CAD team to learn the software and remake those lessons but for Onshape, and we do all machining in house so the CAM capabilities are a must.

posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked: Our team did that last year, we still use fusion for CAM. If you did that I would recomend taking the frcdesign.org course, it covers like everything needed for frc and also install the mkcad addon, it has bearing, motor, and frc miscellaneous models. I use fusion personally I perfer it mote, but with mkcad and the wide viewing capabilities, being able to see anyone’s model with a hyperlink on any device makes it WAY better for frc than fusion

posts.name: Roxxy S
posts.cooked: I will definitely look into these

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: I think you could get macbook airs from 2-3 years ago for $600ish. MacOS supports fusion, and they have pretty good performance and really good battery life.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: Yeah but MacOS

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: If it works it works.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: True, but there are better options for the same price, that’s all I’m getting at.

posts.name: Roxxy S
posts.cooked: I could also get current gen tech for around the same price and I’d get to fix it myself

posts.name: M
posts.cooked: I’ve crashed like 10 times trying to cad anything decently detailed like my robot cad

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: I had that problem last year, but this year our team implemented actually good CAD practices that focused on making things more parametric and have faster regeneration times, and our CAD runs surprisingly well on Chromebooks. Pro tips: don’t use the hole feature if you don’t have to(extrude remove is faster), use linear and circular patterns as well as mirrors(we didn’t know those existed last year and manually dimensioned everything ), and don’t make a separate part studio for every. single. part.(we literally had almost 100 part studios in our CAD last year )

posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked:
Why you should not buy a lot of macs for CAD

does not have a dedicated GPU

runs on mac os that is not compatible with everything

a lot of apple things have features thar need to be paid for

extremely overpriced and not very compatible like windows

apple outdates their devices through excessive demanding updates that really slow down your device

if you want a good battery life don’t get one with a dedicated gpu(it is extremely power hungry).  Apple uses integrated graphics, and newer laptops with integrated graphics (like laptops made after 2017) can run fusion

posts.name: Ryan Reed
posts.cooked:
I highly recommend reaching out to parents and mentors to ask for old laptops from work.

Dated workstation laptops will perform decently well for CAD. You will probably have to replace the drives, most companies will remove the hard drives before allowing them to be donated to avoid leaking anything proprietary. You should be able to reuse the Windows license they had before, since the license is tied to the hardware ID nowadays.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
the Reborn Electronics (DBA StockMustGo) folk got a good writeup recently (that I cannot find now, sorry). Their business is corporate refurbishment, and they have a good reputation.  lots of options in the 300-500 range that would work for CAD.

HP ZBook Studio G7 15.6" i7-10850H @2.70GHz 32GB RAM 512GB SSD NVIDIA Quadro T1000 Windows 11 Pro. NVIDIA Quadro T1000 with Max-Q Design 4GB GDDR6. Hard Drive. Windows 11 Pro. Right Side 1x headphone/microphone combo.

Dell Precision 7560 15.6" i7-11800H 2.30GHz 32GB RAM 512GB SSD NVIDIA Quadro T1200 Windows 11 Pro. NVIDIA Quadro T1200 4GB GDDR6. Headphone jack. Hard Drive. Windows 11 Pro. SD-card slot. Condition: Good.

https://www.ebay.com/itm/167527677808?itmmeta=01JWQ208TKJPP0S9848TEYFW9M&hash=item27016d7f70:g:v3AAAeSw29xoLRFD

Look for i7, real GPU.
